text: I have a beautiful word for you: senescence.

It’s the word for how, as multicellular
organisms age, they die more, and reproduce

less. It’s the deterioration that comes
from getting older.

But there are a few exceptions to this get-older-and-die
thing -- including, it turns out, tiny sea
creatures called hydras.

We humans, like a lot of other animals, experience
a peak period of fertility during the first

third of our lifespans -- the period of our
lives when we’re least likely to die from

most things. Your body is working as well
as it’s ever going to, and you’re as good
as you’re gonna get at firing out babies.

Then, senescence kicks in. All of those things
get less and less true, until eventually,
you die.

For a long time, senescence was thought to
be universal -- that all multicellular organisms

capable of breeding more than once will get
worse at it over time, and the older they

get, the more likely it is that they’ll
die.

Until researchers found that a certain kind
of jellyfish can make itself young again,
a power I would like to have.

According to a study that came out this week
from the Max Planck Institute in Germany,

there’s another exception to this rule:
the hydra.
Not the mythical beast with all the heads.

This hydra is a freshwater polyp that’s
a centimeter long, and reproduces both asexually

and sexually, can regenerate after it’s
been cut into pieces, including being able

to regenerate its ENTIRE HEAD, and, as it
turns out, is pretty much immortal.

Not bad, being immortal and stuff, but I would
like to see it try to host youtube show.

The hydra has fascinated scientists for centuries,
and when they sequenced its genome back in

2010, they discovered that it had the same
number of genes as humans.

We also have a surprising number of genes
in common: including certain genes associated

with Alzheimer’s and Huntington’s disease.
So we’ve been studying these tentacular
little guys ever since.

Because, like, maybe they can magically repair
the neurodegeneration that leads to Alzheimer’s,

that would pretty much be exactly what we
would expect from hydras at this point. Like,
why not?

Because we’ve been watching hydras for so
long, scientists have suspected for a long

time that they don’t senesce. But this was
the first large-scale study that focused on
finding out for sure.

The team followed more than two thousand individual
hydras for a combination of 3.9 million days.The

hydras they studied were between zero and
41 years old, and they observed them over
a period of 8 years.

The result? No decline in fertility, or increase
in mortality, was observed at any point in

the hydra life cycle. Although if they don’t
age, it’s not really a cycle, is it? It’s

more of a life...line. That gets cut off when
they get eaten by something.

And THAT is what I have been able to do that
most hydras can’t. Avoid getting eaten.
So far, at least.

These Hydras reproduced, or “budded,”
about once a month, and they died at a rate

of about one of 167 per year, no matter how
old or young they were.

If the mortality rates observed in this study
continued, that means that in 3000 years,

5% of those hydras would still be alive, if
they were kept safe in the lab. That’d be
a really long experiment.

So how do hydras not decline with age? Well,
there are a lot of factors that might contribute.

They have a relatively simple body plan, and
relatively few different types of cells, which
probably helps.

But the most important factor is most likely
that hydras constantly produce new stem cells.

Every cell in a hydra’s body is replaced
every three to four weeks, by fresh cells
produced by brand new stem cells.

It’s essentially regenerating once a month
-- and in a completely different way from

the jellyfish we talked about earlier, which
reverts to an earlier stage of its life cycle
when it’s stressed.

There’s a lot we might be able learn from
this. What we now know about hydras suggests

that they could hold the keys to big breakthroughs
in research on stem cells, aging, and diseases
like Alzheimer’s.

And while we’re at it, maybe we should leave
little notes in the hydra’s genetic code,

for any future aliens who might one day find
our planet. Maybe they’d sequence the genome

of our immortal little buddies, and it would
say, “WE WERE HERE. -Signed, Humanity.”

And then we could leave a link they could
follow to the last working internet server,

which would just be… Rick Astley’s “Never
Going to Give You Up”.
